'Rudolf Julius Emanuel Clausius' (born 'Rudolf Gottlieb'; 2 January
1822 – 24 August 1888), was a German physicist and mathematician and is
considered one of the central founders of the science of
thermodynamics. By his restatement of Sadi Carnot's principle known
as the Carnot cycle, he put the theory of heat on a truer and sounder basis. His
most important paper, On the mechanical theory of heat, published in 1850, first stated the basic ideas of the second law of
thermodynamics. In 1865 he introduced the concept of entropy. In 1870 he
introduced virial theorem which applied to heat.
